tossups.question: Two of these people are “caught kissing” in a photograph by Lucienne Bloch, while another of these people sits behind eight hand-like bread rolls in a Robert Doisneau photograph. Hans Namuth is best known for his photographs of these people. A bucket of water is thrown past a person of this profession towards three jumping cats in a Philippe Halsmann photograph of one of these people (*) “Atomicus”, while Man Ray photographed a man of this profession dressed as his female alter ego Rrose Selavy. For 10 points, name this profession held by the wife of photographer Alfred Stieglitz, Georgia O’Keeffe.
tossups.answer: artists [accept painters or similar, but specifically do not accept photographers] <JK>

tossups.question: One character in this novel claims that the reason they sketch every new animal that they see is that “whatever in creation exists without my knowledge exists without my consent.” Another character in this novel has the letters “HT” branded on his forehead, and meets the nameless protagonist in a cell in (*) Chihuahua. This novel ends with the “kid” being confronted by the “judge” in an outhouse, after which the latter dances naked with strippers. For 10 points, name this novel about how the kid collects Native American scalps with the Glanton Gang, written by Cormac McCarthy.
tossups.answer: Blood Meridian or The Evening Redness in the West

tossups.question: In January, Allan Candelore sued this company after claiming that its pricing system is discriminatory. Liam Smyth is best known for an event facilitated by this company’s service. In 2015, this company retired their ‘Moments’ service, though they introduced half-hour (*) ‘boosts’ the following year. This company’s most famous product features comments like ‘seize the day’ and ‘the one who sends the first message wins’, cajoling users to converse with their ‘matches’. For ten points, name this app on which users find partners by swiping left and right.

This author’s early works include a biography of a favourite actor, James Dean Is Not Dead. In one novel by this author, a dean uses two champagne bottles to beat Justy and Nails to death, after the murder of a tramp curses a Boston relay team. That novel features a sex scene in which Ezra develops a “bulbous (*) salutation”. This author lambasted Geoff Travis in an autobiography which was controversially first published as a Penguin Modern Classic in 2013. For 10 points, name this author of List of the Lost, best-known for writing “This Charming Man” as the frontman of The Smiths.

A 2005 paper by Mallinson and Childs examines this language’s influence on Appalachian “porch sitters.” Shana Poplack argues that this language diverged from standard settler dialects, while Don Winford argues for influence by substrate (*) creoles. “Snaps” are exchanged in a game exclusive to this language called “The Dozens”. William Labov proved that its features like zero copula, double negatives, and habitual “be” were rule-governed in Language in the Inner City. For 10 points, name this variety of English stigmatised compared to the speech of white Americans.
tossups.answer: AAVE [or African American Vernacular English; also accept just African-American English; prompt on answers like Black English; prompt with “that’s actually a racist term, what is it properly known as?” on ebonics, as that term was invented for the specific purpose of stigmatizing AAVE and its use] <EJW>

tossups.question: A branch of this organisation originated under James C.N. Chambers and Rosie Chappell as a group of seamstresses. Elizabeth Tyler lent her publicity skills to this organization, and it was in part inspired by the novels of Thomas Dixon. D.C. Stephenson’s trial almost destroyed this organization, and it and The ADL arose after the lynching of Leo Frank in (*) Atlanta. Indiana was a stronghold of this organization, which re-emerged after some Georgians saw D.W. Griffith’s The Birth of a Nation. For 10 points, name this American white supremacist organisation.

One author from this country created an emigrant farmer who becomes disfigured after he is cursed by an angry neighbour in the novel The Promised Land. In a play from this country, a greedy shoe factory owner tricks a couple into remortgaging their home so he can take their land. In addition to I Will Marry When I Want, (*) that author from this country also wrote a novel in which Kihika kills a camp warden before being betrayed by Mugo; that novel is A Grain of Wheat. For 10 points, name this country home to Grace Ogot and Ngugi wa Thiong’o, who now writes in Kikuyu.

An Islamist politician from this country was nearly karate-chopped to death in Canada by an exiled Sufi blackbelt. This country targeted “attempted adultery” in the civil war-inducing “September Laws” enacted by Gaafar Nimeiry, who abruptly enacted strict Islamic law in 1983. This country’s leader came to power when followers of Hassan al-Turabi, who (*) invited Osama Bin Laden to move to this country in 1991, ousted the great-grandson of a leader whose successor was defeated at the Battle of Omdurman. For 10 points, name this country led by the genocidal Omar al-Bashir and home to the Mahdists.
tossups.answer: The Republic of Sudan [or Jumhūriyyat as-Sūdān; also accept North Sudan but do not accept or prompt on “South Sudan”] <JG>

tossups.question: This man experienced a possible theophany while threshing wheat in a wine press. This man overhears talk of a vision of a loaf of bread rolling into his enemies’ camp, destroying a tent. This man tested God by leaving a woolen fleece outside overnight, and created (*) an army of 300 men by seeing how soldiers drank water from a stream. He then had that army play a lot of trumpets to scare the Midianites. For 10 points, name this judge who armed his men with torches in jars, providing the logo of a group that leaves Bibles in Hotel rooms.

Recent archaeological work suggests that the first recorded attempt to perform this action took place at Pegwell Bay. A more recent attempt to perform this action took place at Carreg Wastad Head, and was foiled when the cobbler (*) Jemima Nicholas locked 12 men inside a Church. The first English Martello Towers were constructed as a response to fears of this action being performed and Hitler’s plan for this action was called Operation Sea Lion. For 10 points, name this action undertaken by Julius Caesar in 55 BC and William the Conqueror in 1066.
tossups.answer: Invading Britain [accept anything suggesting an invasion or foreign attack on Britain, the UK or England] <SC>

tossups.question: One of Jimmu’s targets in invading Japan was a stone one of these objects belonging to Nigihayahi no Mikoto. The Warlocks of Chiloé use one of these called Caleuche [cal-YOO-chay] in Chilean folklore. Gilgamesh replaces the “stone things” necessary to one of these objects owned by Urshanabi. Hrym will use one of these called (*) Naglfar, which is made of fingernails, to bring soldiers to Ragnarok. Oak from Dodona was used to make one of these, which travelled to Colchis. For 10 points name these objects, one of which was crewed by Jason and the Argonauts.

A state of emergency was declared in response to one of these events in Florida in 2016 following the discharging of water from lake Okeechobee. One of these events in the North Atlantic was triggered by dissolved iron in the ash from the Eyjafjallajokull volcanic eruption. These events often result in local (*) anoxia, and they can occur due to runoff of nitrates and phosphates from fertilisers. For 10 points, name these events where the biomass of water-borne microorganisms rapidly increases.

Daniel DiRocco designed a catalyst for installing stereo•centres at this element. The most common class of pincer ligands use one carbon atom and two atoms of this element as donors. A polyprotic oxoacid of this element is used as a reference standard for NMR spectroscopy on its (*) 31- isotope. Four atoms of this element form tetrahedra in a pyrophoric allotrope of it. Apatite is a common source for this element for its use in fertilisers. Hennig Brand boiled down gallons of urine to isolate, for 10 points, which element used in the heads of matches?

In one work of this type, an old man is found dead with a boot in his mouth, probably related to his fetish for Célestine’s shoes. Characters routinely fall over a scraper as they enter the protagonist’s house in another work of this type. In addition to that work featuring (*) Mr Cummings and Mr Gowing [GOING], a short story of this type concerns Poprishchin, a civil servant who believes he has found letters sent between two dogs, while another describes a bookcase set on hinges acting as the entrance to a secret annex of Prinsengracht 263. For 10 points, name these works, like ones “of a Madman” or “of a Young Girl”.

Two Swedish surgeons have speciously argued that this artist gave God a goitre in one work. This artist included a blue-turbaned figure that may be a self-portrait in a fresco in the Cappella Paolina depicting St. Peter’s crucifixion. This artist of the Doni (*) Tondo surrounded his Separation of Light and Darkness with four “ignudi,” and in another of his works, a cloak vaguely shaped like a human brain enshrouds God as he reaches out to a male nude. For 10 points, name this artist who depicted The Creation of Adam in the Sistine Chapel.
tossups.answer: Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni [accept either underlined portion] <JK>

tossups.question: ‘Hearing the shape of a drum’ asks if you can recover a domain from certain eigenvalues for this operator, the Dirichlet eigenvalues. This operator vanishes on functions whose value at any point is equal to its average value on any sphere centred at that point. (*) Poisson’s equation asks you to recover a function from its value under this operator, which vanishes for harmonic functions. Equal to the sum of the second partial derivatives with respect to each coordinate, or the divergence of gradient, for 10 points, give this operator symbolised del squared and named for a French mathematician.
tossups.answer: The Laplacian [or the Laplace Operator; accept del squared before mentioned but do not accept or prompt on “del” alone] <RF>

tossups.question: In a poem attributed to this author, a saint sheds a tear on a reanimated corpse which then dissolves into dust. One of this author’s poems uses images of Belshazzar’s Feast and the Flood to illustrate its title concept, while in another work by this author, a father dreams of crossing a stream to a beautiful maiden. In another poem by this author of (*) Cleanness, animal carcasses are traded for kisses with a man who brings a green girdle he receives from the wife of Bertilak back to the Knights of the Round Table. For 10 points, name this unknown author of Gawain and the Green Knight.
tossups.answer: the Pearl Poet [accept e.g. “the author of Gawain”, prompt on “unknown” with “name me a work attributed to them?” and then accept if they say “Pearl”, “Gawain”, “Cleanness” or “Patience”] <EJW>

tossups.question: Type 2 neo-natal Bartter's syndrome involves a mutation of the ROMK channel in this structure, which can cause hypokalaemia by diminishing an electrical potential gradient and subsequent ion recycling. Thiazide drugs used to treat heart failure inhibit the sodium-chloride co-transporter in this structure to reduce (*) ECF volume. Countercurrent multiplication establishes a high medullary interstitial osmotic pressure in this structure’s Loop of Henle, allowing the production of concentrated urine. For 10 points, name this functional unit of the kidney.

DESCRIPTION ACCEPTABLE One instance of this action involved the Catholic songwriter Ray Repp’s song “Till You,” and John Snelson argued that an instance of this action brought “a new dramatic tension” to Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto in E Minor. The Puccini Estate claimed that this action was done to a melody from (*) La Fanciulla del West, and it most famously may have been done to a chromatic riff from “Echoes” by Pink Floyd. For 10 points, describe this action by a specific person, allegedly done in works like Jesus Christ Superstar and Phantom of the Opera.
tossups.answer: Andrew Lloyd Webber plagiarising things, allegedly [accept obvious descriptions as long as both the person and action are mentioned; prompt on partial answers] <JG>

tossups.question: Despite winning a massive battle at Berestechko, a ruler of this name ultimately failed to defeat Bohdan Khmelnytsky. A five-day life earned a Capet ruler of this name the epithet “the Posthumous.” A general of this first name earned the epithet “Athlete of Christ” for his brilliant “Long Campaign” against (*) the Ottomans. Henry the Navigator was the son of a king of this name and was supported by another, and a French king of this name was captured at Poitiers. For 10 points, give this name of an English king called “Lackland.”
tossups.answer: John [or Jean, Jan, João, or Janos or any other equivalent name] <SC/JG>

tossups.question: [Composer and title of piece required] John Rutter edited the first published score for this work, but after the discovery of a score annotated by its composer, a new edition was published by Jean-Michel Nectoux. The sixth movement of this work begins with a baritone solo which is later repeated by unison choir. Triplet ‘A’s in the horns signal the beginning of the (*) “Dies illa, dies irae” section of that movement, titled “Libera me”. Sopranos sing the melody over broken D major chords in this piece’s last movement, “In Paradisum”, and a soprano soloist sings the fourth movement “Pie Jesu”. For 10 points, identify this D minor mass for the dead, written by the French composer of a famous Pavane.

The most influential Perso-Islamic formulation of the “circle of equity” is found in a work of this title by Naṣīr al-Dīn Ṭūsī. A work of this title builds its ideas on the concept of human “betweenness” and is by Tetsuro Watsuji. A work of this title distinguishes between “adequate” and “inadequate” ideas and (*) posits a drive to “persevere in [one’s own] being” called conatus. That work analyses passions in the section “Of Human Bondage” and expounds the title subject “in geometric order.” For 10 points give this title of the pantheist magnum opus of Baruch Spinoza.
tossups.answer: Ethics [also accept any of Ethica, ’Akhlāq, or Rinrigaku] <JG>

tossups.question: In these systems, CMA diagrams can be used to categorise oscillations and show their wave normal surfaces. Electromagnetic waves can undergo non-collisional attenuation in these systems in Landau damping. Low frequency vibrations called (*) Alfven waves can occur in these systems whose time evolution is described by the Vlasov equation. One of these quasi-neutral substances is confined by a toroidal magnetic field in a tokamak reactor for nuclear fusion. Ionisation of a gas generates, for 10 points, what “fourth state of matter”?

In the 2016 Big Bash League, this player bowled a miraculous four over spell in which he took 3-3, the most economical figures in the history of the league. In the 4th test of the 2015 Ashes, this player top scored for Australia with 13 in the first innings. Though in the 2010/11 Ashes series this player was taunted for (*) ‘bowling to the left’ and ‘bowling to the right’, he bounced back in the 2013/14 series to take 37 wickets at an average of 13.97. For 10 points, name this Australian fast bowler who became known for his incredible speed and handlebar moustache.

bonuses.leadin: “A true gentleman leaves no puzzle unsolved!” For 10 points each, answer some questions on archaeologist extraordinaire, Professor Layton.
answer: The Eternal Diva [accept Eien no Utahime; prompt on The First Movie or Za Fāsuto Mūbī] <LC>
parts: Give the English subtitle of the second game in the series, in which Layton travels across the country by train to find the eponymous item. In mythology, this object was left with only ‘Hope’ inside.

“Objection!” is the catchphrase of this ace attorney with whom Layton came face-to-face in a crossover game for Nintendo 3DS. It made use of their respective skills to solve the mystery of Labyrinthia.

Based on the Level-5 series, this was the subtitle of the 2009 film directed by Masakazu Hashimoto. The story followed the titular songstress whose music caused the ruins of Ambrosia to rise out of the sea.

bonuses.leadin: The surface states of a topological insulator can be modeled as one of these systems. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these systems which can also be used to model the behaviour of n-doped rectangular quantum wells.
The layer of electrons found in these components can also be modeled as two-dimensional electron gases. These devices have largely superseded bipolar junction transistors.
Two-dimensional electron gases can exhibit a quantum version of this effect. In this effect, a potential difference is generated transverse to a conductor in a magnetic field.

bonuses.leadin: One of this man’s paintings, La Femme au Cheval, was hung by Niels Bohr in his office and is sometimes said to have inspired the development of quantum mechanics. For ten points each:
answer: Cubisme (accept specific subfields like analytic or synthetic cubism)
parts: Name this French painter, heavily inspired by mathematician Maurice Princet, whose portrait Le gouter, or Tea Time, is sometimes called the Mona Lisa of his artistic movement.

Along with Albert Gleizes, Metzinger argued that this movement’s art was based in Riemannian geometry in their manifesto for this movement, whose better-known figures included Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque.

This artist’s prodigious maths studies inspired his attempts to paint the fourth dimension in works like Sad Young Man on a Train. Before turning to chess, he produced a Cubist painting derided as “an explosion in a shingle factory”.

bonuses.leadin: Early trade between Europeans and people from what is now this country centered on sandalwood and sea cucumbers, and a third of its population descends from indentured Indian sugarcane workers. For 10 points each:
answer: the Republic of Fiji [or the Matanitu Tugalala o Viti, though that is in fact pronounced “Fiji”]
whales [anti-prompt on specific types of whales] (tabua are carved sperm whale teeth)

Cannibal forks [accept descriptive answers; prompt on forks] (Ratu Udre Udre continues to hold the Guinness Book of World Records title of “most prolific cannibal”; the “Cannibal Isle” reputation of Fiji was part of the justification for colonising it) <HO>
parts: Name this Pacific island nation, whose crown colony was created by Hercules Robinson and Arthur Gordon after its 1874 cession by Ratu Cakobau. Currently led by Frank Bainimarama, it has seen four coups since 1970.

One prized type of trade good from Fiji is the tabua, an object made from this animal used to seek honor or forgiveness from Fijian chiefs. New Bedford and Nantucket were key colonial bases for hunting this animal for oil.

The sale of these hardwood objects, typically given a “squid-like” shape by three to four tines, exploits Fiji’s fearsome pre-colonial reputation. They were presumably most prolifically used by the infamous Ratu Udre Udre.

bonuses.leadin: In 1999, a musical based on this man’s choreography opened on Broadway, featuring numbers like “Steam Heat” and “Big Spender”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this jazz choreographer. He won a record eight Tony awards and an Oscar for Cabaret, which featured his trademark saucy style, using turned-in knees, sideways shuffling and rolled shoulders.

Another classic Fosse hallmark was this campy move, which featured in nearly all of his choreography. He used this move to open the musical Pippin, illuminating the cast’s wiggling fingers against a black backdrop.

Fosse choreographed much of his work for this woman, his second wife. He directed this performer in productions of Damn Yankees, Sweet Charity and Chicago, in which she originated the role of Roxie Hart.

bonuses.leadin: This set of texts was discovered at Nag Hammadi in Upper Egypt, and it includes the Gospel of Philip and The Hypostasis of the Archons. For 10 points each:
answer: “Doubting” Thomas the Apostle [also accept however you say “Thomas” in Malayalam, Aramaic, or Greek]
parts: Name this set of early Christian apocryphal texts, which shows the initial influence of ideas from Hermeticism and Simon Magus, and contains several beliefs about figures like Ialdabaoth and the Demiurge.

The most widely studied of the Gnostic Gospels is a sayings Gospel supposedly written by this disciple, also known as Didymus. In John 20:27, Jesus tells him to “reach hither thy finger and thrust into my side.”

This Princeton scholar popularised the term “Gnostic Gospels” in a book of that name. This Nag Hammadi studies pioneer has argued that Paul was in fact a gnostic and that many early Christians did not view Jesus as God.

bonuses.leadin: These organelles can be derived from the endoplasmic reticulum, and undergo fission, producing daughters to increase their number within the cell. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this eukaryotic organelle, whose major metabolic functions include beta-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids to medium chain fatty acids, which in animals, are then shuttled to the mitochondrion.
This autosomal recessive disorder, named for a Swiss-American pediatrician, is characterised by the depletion or absence of functional peroxisomes. It is associated with impaired neuronal migration.
Peroxisomes also perform this type of reaction on potentially harmful reactive oxygen species. This type of reaction is characterised by a gain of electrons.

bonuses.leadin: For a man who wrote a load of stuff, especially about people talking, Plato really didn’t seem to like writing and talking that much. For 10 points each:
answer: rhetoric [also accept oratory and word forms]
The Republic [also accept Politeia or Res Publica] <JK>
parts: Plato has Socrates attack this field in both Phaedrus and Gorgias, in the latter of which Socrates calls this field a “flattery” while asking Gorgias the value of teaching it. Quintilian wrote a popular guide to this field.

This Plato work includes the quote "every serious man dealing with really serious subjects carefully avoids writing." This work mainly contains Plato’s complaints about working in the court of Dion of Syracuse.
This long Plato dialogue includes his decision that frivolous writers, especially poets, should be banished from the ideal city Kallipolis, run by philosopher-kings, that titles the work.

bonuses.leadin: A luxury magazine set up in this book is titled Ogee [Oh-gee], after the s-shaped double curve. For 10 points each:
answer: Margaret Hilda Thatcher, Baroness Thatcher, LG, OM, PC <JS>
parts: Name this Man Booker winning novel, whose main character Nick is writing a PhD on Henry James. His conquests include a waiter Tristao, Wani Ouradi, and Leo, a black man from Willesden.
The Line of Beauty is a 2004 Man Booker Prize winning novel by this British author, who also wrote The Swimming Pool Library and The Stranger’s Child.

At a party held by his host, Gerald Fadden, Nick gets high on coke and dances “rather sexily” to the Rolling Stones with this Prime Minister. This woman remarks that “It’s not often one gets asked to dance by a don.”

bonuses.leadin: The year 1685 saw the births of many notable composers. For 10 points each:
parts: This Italian composer born in 1685 spent much of his career serving the Portuguese and Spanish royal families. Most of his 555 keyboard sonatas went unpublished until after his death.

Another famous composer born in the same year was George Frideric Handel. This earliest surviving autographed work of Handel was written for five vocal soloists and five-part chorus, and is a setting of Psalm 110.
Also born in 1685 was Lodovico Giustini, the first known composer ever to write music specifically for this keyboard instrument, which was invented by Bartolomeo Cristofori around 1700.

bonuses.leadin: One of the major products of the ancient world was dead people. For 10 points each:
answer: the Valley of the Kings [also accept Valley of the Gates of the Kings or in Arabic Wādī Abwāb al-Mulūk or Wādī al-Mulūk]
the Mycenaean Greeks [prompt on Greeks or Hellenes; do not accept or prompt on “Minoans”] <SC>
parts: One of the most famous places to store dead people produced by the ancient world is this Egyptian site, home to Tutankhamun’s tomb, and many others.
This site northwest of Persepolis was the necropolis of the Achaemenid dynasty. It is also home to a square tower called the “Cube of Zoroaster” and includes several impressive rock reliefs.

Like some Cypriots and Thracians, this civilization is noted for “beehive” tombs called tholoi. Their burials often contained their distinctive boars’ tusks helmets and inscriptions in Linear B but not Linear A.

bonuses.leadin: This man names the slightly ridiculous chess opening ‘pawn to a3’, which is mainly useful for psyching people out. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this German chess master of the mid-19th century, who used flamboyant sacrifices to win what are now called the ‘Immortal Game’ and the ‘Evergreen Game’.

In 1858, Anderssen lost badly to this chess prodigy from New Orleans, who is the centre of the chess equivalent of the Kevin Bacon number. While trying to watch Norma, he sublimely attacked two amateurs to win the Opera Game.

This later American chess player was a fan of Morphy, describing him as “the most accurate player who ever lived”. He feuded with Boris Spassky in the 1960s and 70s, before going rather insane and moving to Iceland.

bonuses.leadin: This shape is created in electrospinning as a small volume of conductive solution is accelerated by an electric potential. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this shape also observed in electrospraying and focused ion beams.
Electrospray ionisation is used to prepare samples for this technique. MALDI and EI are other methods for preparing samples for this technique.
Electrospraying generates one of these colloids, which comprise liquid droplets evenly distributed in a gas. CFCs were formerly used as propellants to generate these colloids in a type of spray can.

bonuses.leadin: Authors often seem to end up leaving their life’s work on trains. For 10 points each:
answer: Thomas Edward Lawrence, or Lawrence of Arabia
parts: While in London to get Yeats to write an introduction for this collection, Tagore left his only copy of it on the Tube. Luckily, it ended up at the Lost Property Office, allowing him to win the Nobel for this work.

This author was less lucky when he lost his manuscript of The Seven Pillars of Wisdom while changing trains in Reading; he had to rewrite all 250,000 words of it. The work discusses this author’s career in the Middle East.

Another example of train-based literary misfortune, this time fictional, occurs when this professor of Russian at Waindell College loses his lecture notes and some student essays, while on a train to Cremona.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about socialist missteps in a particular Eastern Bloc nation, for 10 points each:
answer: Fidesz-Hungarian Civic Alliance [accept either underlined portion or Magyar Polgári Szövetség. Oddly enough, the post-1989 Hungarian Socialist Party was almost entirely economically laissez-faire]
parts: Imre Nagy’s trusting Soviet promises of safe passage after this country’s 1956 uprising failed was a bit of a fatal misstep. Afterwards, Janos Kadar made this country the “happiest barrack” with his “goulash communism.”

Socialist Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsány’s expletive-laden 2006 Őszöd speech, in which he claims his party spent his term lying and doing nothing, led directly to the dominance of this right-wing party led by Viktor Orbán.

This man led a brutal, short-lived Hungarian Soviet Republic in 1919 until a Romanian invasion. His Lenin Youth’s Red Terror cratered his popularity, but his main misstep was thinking Stalin wouldn’t purge him.

bonuses.leadin: In one novel, this author reflects on two uses of the word “no” in his life; one when his wife suggests they have children, and one when he is asked by a doctor whether he has children. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author who wrote about refusing to bring new life into a world that allowed the Holocaust in Kaddish for an Unborn Child, and of a child’s experience in Buchenwald in Fateless.

This author from the same country as Kertész writes about a circus that only has a whale in The Melancholy of Resistance, and how farmers escape from their masters in an authoritarian society in Satantango.
Kertész and Krasznahorkai are both from this Central European nation, whose other contemporary authors include Péter Nádas and whose national epic is The Siege of Sziget.

bonuses.leadin: Richard Neville, 16<sup>th</sup> Earl Warwick, had an absurdly complicated Coat of Arms. For 10 points each, answer some questions about the families connected by them:
parts: The quartering ‘Or three Chevrons Gules’ have been associated since 1141 with this surname, now shared with a Cambridge college. They were earls of Hertford and Gloucester in the 12th and 13th century.

Sharing the fourth quarter with Clare, the Arms associated with this surname figure in the Arms of Winston Churchill and Princess Diana. The 1st Earl of Winchester, a reviled adviser to Edward II, had this surname.

The third quarter shows the Arms of Neville differenced by a label suggesting allegiance with this rival house of the House of York, due to Warwick’s descent from John of Gaunt through his grandmother Joan Beaufort.

bonuses.leadin: You are a frustrated undergraduate attempting to learn to code using MATLAB. Answer the following about irritating difficulties you may encounter, for 10 points each:
answer: % [accept percentage sign from people who can’t pronounce symbols] <JK>
parts: You soon find that the tilde appended before an equals sign denotes this logic gate, unlike in many languages where it is represented by an exclamation mark.

After accidentally taking the dot product of two lists of text, you realise that MATLAB interprets all 1D arrays as these mathematical constructs. They can be represented by arrows and are contrasted with scalars.

When you follow good practice and insert comments about all these problems, you discover that MATLAB uses this unusual symbol for starting comments. In languages like Python it is used to perform modular arithmetic.

bonuses.leadin: Oxfam has really not been having a good few weeks. For 10 points each:
parts: The charity is currently facing intense scrutiny over a scandal in this country. It emerged that workers delivering aid after a 2010 earthquake in this country had used prostitutes, many of whom were underage.

The scandal has prompted the deputy chief executive of Oxfam to resign, and patrons to step down. This Secretary for International Development has called for a full investigation, and threatened to strip the charity of its funding.

In a separate, badly-timed blow for the charity, this chairman of Oxfam International has also been arrested in Guatemala, as part of an investigation into corruption during his time as the country’s finance minister.

bonuses.leadin: This analytical framework invokes the economic domination of “periphery” countries or regions by a “core” territory or power centre. For 10 points each:
answer: World-Systems Theory/Analysis [accept the world-economy] (yes, Janet Abu-Lughod is Lila’s mother, if anybody’s wondering)
parts: Name this model of history and geopolitics notably employed by Janet Abu-Lughod and Immanuel Wallerstein, the latter of whom saw its origins in sixteenth-century capitalist agriculture.

This author of The Development of Underdevelopment contends that the world-system had already formed by 1500. He described Song China's dominance of the world-system in ReOrient: Global Economy in the Asian Age.
Wallerstein suggested that the presence of the world-system implies that this process, sometimes defined as increasing worldwide interconnection and interdependence, has been happening for 500 years.

bonuses.leadin: As humanity pumps more CO2 into the atmosphere, the ocean too is suffering. For 10 points each:
parts: If ocean temperatures rise 1 degree above their usual range for a sustained period, this phenomenon occurs, where coral reefs lose their vibrant colours.
Bleaching happens because the coral expels these photosynthetic organisms that provide it with food, meaning that it starves and dies if elevated temperatures persist too long.
One area that has been particularly badly hit by bleaching in recent years is this largest coral reef on the planet, which endured successive, widespread bleaching events in 2016 and 2017.

bonuses.leadin: According to one poem, when one of these animals went “out of sight, it marked the edge of one of many circles”, and “among twenty snowy mountains, the only moving thing” was the eye of one of these animals. For 10 points each:
answer: Peter Quince (at the Clavier) [prompt on Peter] <JK>
parts: Name this animal, which that poem gives “thirteen ways of looking at”.
Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird is a poem by this American Modernist poet of The Emperor of Ice-Cream, who produced much of his work while working full-time as an insurance executive.
In another poem by Stevens, this Shakespearean character describes how “the self-same sounds on my spirit make a music, too” while playing that poem’s title instrument.

bonuses.leadin: One prominent artist in a school named for this French palace painted Christ’s deposition from the cross for an altarpiece in Volterra. For 10 points each:
answer: Cuzco [also accept answers that pronounce the “z” more like an “s”; also accept the Esquela Cusqueña/Cusqueña School] <JK>
parts: Name this château southeast of Paris, where Francis I invited painters like Francesco Primaticcio and Niccolo dell’Abbate to form a namesake Mannerist school.

An Italian Mannerist, Parmigianino, made self-portrait in a “convex” one of these objects, distorting his hand. Yayoi Kusama built several “infinity rooms” of these objects, and one hangs on the wall in the Arnolfini Wedding.

Spanish Mannerists inspired the development of a school of religious art in this South American city. Diego Quispe Tito worked in this city, where Marcos Zapata depicted a guinea pig about to be eaten in his Last Supper.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about African creation myths, sadly none of which involve the Kuba myth in which Mbombo vomits up the rest of creation. For 10 points each:
answer: Australian Aborigines [also accept more specific Australian Aboriginal peoples]
death [accept any answer that gets across humans being mortal, prompt on answers like aging or illness]

the deus otiosus motif/archetype [or the idle god motif; also accept the deus absconditus or hidden god; also accept Wilhelm Schmidt’s Urmonotheist god and word-forms though they’re not really the same things; these are all technical terms, largely from Mircea Eliade, so exact wording is required] <JG>
parts: The Fon believe that Nana Buluku created the world while riding a rainbow serpent. These non-African people believe that a rainbow serpent was involved in the creation of the world during the Dreamtime.

In Uganda’s Legend of Kintu this phenomenon occurs because Kintu’s annoying brother-in-law followed his wife. In Polynesian myth, it occurs because the hoopoe laughed before Māui could crawl through Hine-nui-te-pō.

The Baluba god Kabezya-Mpungu is a textbook example of this motif, as he literally made himself invisible to the world. This archetype, like the Yoruba’s Olorun, kickstarts creation but has few other interactions with it.
